description: Number of n-state Turing machines which halt.
comments: This sequence is noncomputable, because it could be used to solve the halting problem. In fact, it is of the same degree of difficulty as the halting problem. - David Diamondstone (skeptical.scientist(AT)gmail.com), Dec 28 2007
references: N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: J. P. Jones, Recursive undecidability - an exposition, Amer. Math. Monthly, 81 (1974), 724-738.
Index entries for sequences related to Busy Beaver problem
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
extensions: More terms from David Diamondstone (skeptical.scientist(AT)gmail.com), Dec 28 2007
a(4) from _Jonathan Lee_, who enumerated all 25.6 billion 4-state machines up to 107 steps, Mar 05 2016
